question: Tell me -- do you think about hell? No -- neither do I. But... but this man is a Christian and he has written -- A -- a week. Why -- I -- I have a ticket. A First Class ticket. I sent for it in the post. I'm an attorney, and I didn't have time to -- No, no -- just a moment, please. You see, Mohandas K. Gandhi, Attorney at Law. I am going to Pretoria to conduct a case for an Indian trading firm. Sir, I was called to the bar in London and enrolled in the High Court of Chancery -- I am therefore an attorney, and since I am -- in your eyes -- colored -- I think we can deduce that there is at least one colored attorney in South Africa. I always go First Class! I have traveled all over England and I've never... But you're a rich man -- why do you put up with it?
answer: I'm rich -- but I'm Indian. I therefore do not expect to travel First Class.

question: In England, I was a poor student but
answer: That was England.

question: This part of "England's" Empire! But that is very un-Christian. You mean you employ Mr. Baker as your attorney, but you can't walk down the street with him?
answer: I can. But I risk being kicked into the gutter by someone less "holy" than Mr. Baker.

question: Well, then, it must be fought. We are children of God like everyone else.
answer: Allah be praised. And what battalions will you call upon?

question: I -- I will write to the press -- here -- and in England. And I will use the courts. We are members of the Empire. And we come from an ancient civilization. Why should we not walk on the pavements like other men?
answer: I rather like the idea of an Indian barrister in South Africa. I'm sure our community could keep you in work for some time, Mr. Gandhi -- even if you caused a good deal of trouble. Especially if you caused a good deal of trouble.

question: There's the English reporter. I told you he'd come.
answer: You also said your article would draw a thousand people. At least some of the Hindus brought their wives.

question: No. I asked my wife to organize that. Ladies and Gentlemen, we have asked you to gather here to help us proclaim our right to be treated as equal citizens of the Empire. We do not seek conflict. We know the strength of the forces arrayed against us, know that because of them we can only use peaceful means -- but we are determined that justice will be done! The symbol of our status is embodied in this pass -- which we must carry at all times, but no European even has to have. And the first step to changing our status is to eliminate this difference between us.
answer: You write brilliantly, but you have much to learn about handling men. We do not want to ignite... the fear or hatred of anyone. But we ask you -- Hindu, Muslim and Sikh -- to help us light up the sky... and the minds of the British authorities -- with our defiance of this injustice. We will now burn the passes of our committee and its supporters. We ask you to put your passes on the fire with --

question: You saved the papers.
answer: I wish you were still struggling for work in Bombay.

question: I hated that -- all the pettiness, the little corruptions. And I was more laughing stock than lawyer. But they needed me here. If I'd never been thrown off that train, perhaps no one would ever have needed me. "A high court judge has confirmed that Mr. Gandhi would have been within his rights to prosecute for assault since neither he nor Mr. Khan resisted arrest." -- I told you about English law.
answer: As I told you about English policemen.

question: Yes? And I am glad to be back. Come...
answer: Be careful!

question: Tomorrow I will tell you what it feels like to be a jailbird. Just like proper English gentlemen. I'm proud of them.
answer: They are boys. -- And they're Indian.

question: Hm. Will you take this off? It pinches every time I speak. Here, you see? Even the South African papers apologize -- "a monstrous attack."
answer: Are you sure?

question: Yes -- I can't talk like this. Pull! Oww!
answer: Mr. Khan said they called you brave.

question: If you would let me teach you to read, you could see for yourself.
answer: I could have told them you were merely foolish.

question: It proves what I told you. If I had prosecuted him as everyone advised -- even you -- they would have hated me -- by showing forgiveness I -- ouch!
answer: There...

question: You see there is such a thing as moral force -- and it can be harnessed.
answer: Not always. You have told me twice now that you were giving up the pleasures of the flesh.

question: I am. I am convinced the holy men are right. When you give up, you gain. The simpler your life the better. I will fast tomorrow -- as a penance.
answer: If you enjoy it a great deal you must fast for two days.

question: You'd be Gandhi -- ...I thought you'd be bigger.
answer: I'm sorry.

question: I -- I mean it's all right. It doesn't matter. I'm -- my name is Andrews, Charlie Andrews. I've come from India -- I've read a great deal about you.
answer: Some of it good, I hope. Would you care to walk? You're a clergyman.

question: Yes. I've -- I've met some very remarkable people in India... and -- and when I read what you've been doing here, I -- I wanted to help. Does that surprise you?
answer: Not anymore. At first I was amazed... but when you are fighting in a just cause, people seem to pop up -- like you -- right out of the pavement. Even when it is dangerous or --

question: Perhaps I should --
answer: Doesn't the New Testament say, "If your enemy strikes you on the right cheek, offer him the left"?

question: I think perhaps the phrase was used metaphorically... I don't think our Lord meant --
answer: I'm not so certain. I have thought about it a great deal. I suspect he meant you must show courage -- be willing to take a blow -- several blows -- to show you will not strike back -- nor will you be turned aside... And when -- ...and when you do that it calls upon something in human nature -- something that makes his hate for you diminish and his respect increase. I think Christ grasped that and I -- I have seen it work. Good morning. You'll find there's room for us both.

question: That was lucky.
answer: I thought you were a man of God.

question: I am. But I'm not so egotistical as to think He plans His day around my dilemmas.
answer: ...you could call it a "communal farm," I suppose. But we've all come to the same conclusion -- our Gita, the Muslim's Koran or your Bible -- it's always the simple things that catch your breath -- "Love thy neighbor as thyself" -- not always practiced -- but it's something we Hindus could learn a lot from.

question: That's the sort of thing you'll be seeking on this "farm"...
answer: Well, we shall try.

question: ...so it's not "spiritualism" or "nationalism" -- we're not against anything but the idea that people can't live together. You see -- Hindus, Muslims, Sikhs, Jews -- even Christians. Mr. Walker! Of The New York Times! Without a paper -- a journal of some kind -- you cannot unite a community. You belong to a very important profession.
answer: Hm. And what should an "important professional" write about your response to General Smuts's new legislation?

question: I don't know... I'm still searching for a "response."
answer: You will respect the law.

question: There are unjust laws -- as there are unjust men.
answer: You're a very small minority to take on the Government -- and the Empire.

question: If you are a minority of one, the truth is the truth. This is Mr. Kallenbach. He is our chief carpenter -- and also our chief benefactor. He has made this experiment possible.
answer: Well, it's quite a place, your "ashram" -- is that right?

question: That's right. The word only means "community." But it could stand for "village"... or the world.
answer: You're an ambitious man.

question: I hope not.
answer: They tell me you also take your turn at peeling potatoes and cleaning the "outhouse" -- is that part of the experiment?

question: Ba -- we will need another place set for Mr. Walker's driver.
answer: I will tell Sora.

question: It's one way to learn that each man's labor is as important as another's. In fact when you're doing it, "cleaning the outhouse" seems far more important than the law. Please come and join us -- you'll need something before your journey back. Excuse me a moment. What is it?
answer: Sora was sent to tell me I -- I must rake and cover the latrine.

question: Everyone takes his turn.
answer: It is the work of untouchables.

question: In this place there are no untouchables -- and no work is beneath any of us!
answer: I am your wife.

question: All the more reason.
answer: As you command. The others may follow you -- but you forget, I knew you when you were a boy!

question: It's not me. It's the principle. And you will do it with joy or not do it at all!
answer: Not at all then...

question: All right, go! You don't belong here! Go! Leave the ashram! Get out altogether! We don't want you!
answer: Stop it! Stop it! What are you doing!? Have you no shame? I'm your wife... Where do you expect me to go?

question: What is the matter with me...?
answer: You are human -- only human. And it is even harder for those of us who do not even want to be as good as you do.

question: I apologize... I must go back to that reporter.
answer: ...And I must rake and cover the latrine.

question: And a policeman passing an Indian dwelling -- I will not call them homes -- may enter and demand the card or any Indian woman whose dwelling it is. Understand! He does not have to stand at the door -- he may enter. I praise such courage. I need such courage -- because in this cause, I too am prepared to die... But, my friend, there is no cause for which I am prepared to kill. I have asked you here tonight because despite all their troops and police, I think there is a way to defeat this law. Whatever they do to us we will attack no one, kill no one... But we will not give our fingerprints -- not one of us. They will imprison us, they will fine us. They will seize our possessions. But they cannot take away our self-respect if we do not give it to them. I am asking you to fight -- ! To fight against their anger -- not to provoke it! We will not strike a blow -- but we will receive them. And through our pain we will make them see their injustice and it will hurt, as all fighting hurts! ...But we cannot lose. We cannot. Because they may torture my body, may break my bones, even kill me... They will then have my dead body -- not my obedience. We are Hindu and Muslim -- children of God, each of us. Let us take a solemn oath in His name that -- come what may -- we will not submit to this law. God save our gracious King... Long live our ...noble King. God save the King!! You have put their comrades in jail. When you free them they will go back to work. We have warned each other.
answer: At the canter -- for-ward!

question: Lie down! Lie down!
answer: You're right!

question: Lie down! Lie down!
answer: Follow me! What the hell are we supposed to do now?

question: They're sparing no one, I see.
answer: No. You were the surprise. It's been all over the prison. We thought they'd be too afraid of the English press.

question: So did I.
answer: Don't worry about the meat -- it's Hindu -- there's not a trace. I don't know who they've left out there to do the work. There can't be one mine left open. Have they touched the women?

question: My wife publicly defied the law. They've arrested her and four others.
answer: The fools! Sorry...

question: It's split the Government.
answer: Well, that's one victory.

question: If we hold firm, it won't be the last.
answer: Don't worry -- I've never seen men so determined. You've given them a way to fight... And I don't think --

question: Ah, Mr. Gandhi. I thought we might have a little talk. Will you have a glass of sherry?
answer: Thank you. No.

question: Perhaps some tea?
answer: I dined at the prison.

question: Ahh. Please -- please do come and sit down. It's prison I wanted to talk to you about. Mr. Gandhi, I've more or less decided to ask the House to repeal the Act that you have taken such "exception" to.
answer: Well, if you ask, General Smuts, I'm sure it will be done.

question: Hm. Of course it is not quite that simple.
answer: Somehow I expected not.

question: I'm glad to hear you say that... very glad. You see if we repeal the Act under pressure under this kind of pressure it will create a great deal of resentment. Can you understand that?
answer: Very well.

question: Good. Good. I have thought of calling for a Royal Commission to "investigate" the new legislation. I think I could guarantee they would recommend the Act be repealed.
answer: I congratulate them.

question: But they might also recommend that future Indian immigration be severely restricted -- even stopped.
answer: Immigration was not an issue on which we fought. It would be wrong of us to make it one now that we -- we are in a position of advantage.

question: You're an extraordinary man.
answer: I assure you I feel a very ordinary man at this moment.

question: I'm ordering the release of all prisoners within the next twenty- four hours. You yourself are free from this moment. Assuming we are in agreement?
answer: Yes -- yes. It's just that... in these clothes I'd -- I'd prefer to go by taxi.

question: All right. Fine.
answer: I'm -- I'm afraid I have no money.

question: Oh! Neither have I. I'm awfully sorry. Daniels, would you lend Mr. Gandhi a shilling for a taxi? How far will you be going, Mr. Gandhi?
answer: Well -- now that this is settled -- I had thought seriously of going back to India but a shilling will do splendidly for the moment. Thank you. Thank you both for a very enlightening experience. I'm obliged, Mr. Daniels, but I will find my own way out.

question: He's either a great man or a colossal fraud... Either way, I shall be glad to see the last of him.
answer: No, no, I haven't "refused"... I -- I simply wanted to dress the way my comrades in prison dressed. I -- I have demanded rights as a British citizen, it is therefore my duty to help in the defense of the British Empire. I don't know... I don't know...

question: Who is that young man?
answer: That's young Nehru. He's got his father's intellect, his mother's looks and the devil's charm. If they don't ruin him at Cambridge -- Wave! Wave! -- he may amount to something. I must say when I first saw you as a bumbling lawyer here in Bombay I never thought I'd be greeting you as a national hero.

question: I'm hardly that, Mr. Patel.
answer: Oh, yes, you are. It's been two hundred years since an Indian has cocked a snoot at the British Empire and got away with it. And stop calling me Mr. Patel, you're not a junior clerk anymore.

question: No.
answer: The new Military Governor of the North West Province was on that ship. Too bad you came back Third Class -- he might have been impressed by a successful barrister who had outmaneuvered General Smuts.

question: Thank you . . .
answer: I try to live like an Indian, as you see... it is stupid of course, because in our country it is the British who decide how an Indian lives -- what he may buy, what he may sell. And from their luxury in the midst of our terrible poverty they instruct us on what is justice and what is sedition. So it is only natural that our best young minds assume an air of Eastern dignity, while greedily assimilating every Western weakness as quickly as they can acquire it.

question: If we have Home Rule that will change.
answer: Would you, please? And why should the English grant us Home Rule? Here, we must take the peelings to the goats. We only make wild speeches, or perform even wilder acts of terrorism. We've bred an army of anarchists but not one single group that can really fight the British anywhere.

question: I thought you were against fighting.
answer: Just spread it around -- they like the new peelings mixed with the rotting ones. Where there is injustice, I've always believed in fighting. The question is do you fight to change things, or do you fight to punish. For myself, I have found that we are all such sinners we should leave punishment to God. And if we really want to change things there are better ways of doing it than by derailing trains or slashing someone with a sword.

question: Clear the way there! Get out of the way! Give me a leg up, will you! What the hell is it, Sergeant? Jesus...! What the hell is going on? Who the hell is he? Who the devil are you?
answer: My name is Gandhi. Mohandas K. Gandhi.

question: Well, whoever you are, we don't want you here. I suggest you get back on that train before it leaves the station.
answer: They seem to want me.

question: Now look here. I'll put you under arrest if you'd prefer?
answer: On what charge?

question: I don't want any trouble.
answer: I am an Indian traveling in my own country. I see no reason for trouble.

question: Well, there'd better not be.
answer: I understand. The landlords are British? What we can do... we will try to do. Is all Champaran like this, Shukla? Yes. I am not sorry at all.

question: I understand. The landlords are British? What we can do... we will try to do. Is all Champaran like this, Shukla? Yes. I am not sorry at all.
answer: I wish to see the prisoner, please.

question: Charlie--
answer: ...Shades of South Africa.

question: Not quite. They're only "holding me" until the Magistrate's hearing. Then it will be prison.
answer: Did they take your clothes?

question: These are my clothes now.
answer: You always had a puritanical streak, Mohan.

question: If I want to be one with them, I have to live like them.
answer: I think you do. But I thank God we all don't.

question: I'm sure your legs are quite as handsome as mine.
answer: Ah, but my puritanism runs the another way. I'm far too modest for such a display. Couldn't I be let in with the prisoner? I am a clergyman. They're calling you "Bapu." I thought it meant father.

question: It does. We must be getting old, Charlie.
answer: What do you want me to do?

question: I think, Charlie, that you can help us most by taking that assignment you've been offered in Fiji. I have to be sure -- they have to be sure -- that what we do can be done by Indians... alone. But you know the strategy. The world is full of people who will despise what's happening here. It is their strength we need. Before you go, you could start us in the right direction.
answer: I must leave from Calcutta, and soon. You'll have to say goodbye to Ba for me.

question: When I get the chance.
answer: Well, I --

question: There are no goodbyes for us, Charlie. Wherever you are, you will always be in my heart...
answer: I am going to clear the courtroom. I don't know where they found the nerve for all this. How the press get here before the military? You have been ordered out of the province on the grounds of disturbing the peace.

question: With respect, I refuse to go.
answer: Do you want to go to jail?

question: As you wish.
answer: All right. I will release you on bail of one hundred rupees until I reach a sentence.

question: I refuse to pay one hundred rupees.
answer: Then I -- I will grant release without bail -- until I reach a decision.

question: I don't know what this country is coming to!
answer: But good God, man, you yourself raised the rent simply to finance a hunting expedition! And some of these others -- beatings, illegal seizures, demanding services without pay, even refusing them water! In India!...

question: Nobody knows what it is to try to get these people to work!
answer: Well, you've make this half-naked whatever-he-is into an international hero. "One lone man marching dusty roads armed only with honesty and a bamboo shaft doing battle with the British Empire." At home children are writing "essays" about him. I couldn't take another two years of him to save my life.

question: What do they want? That would satisfy him?...
answer: And His Majesty's Government. It only needs your signature for the landlords.

question: It will be worth it to see the back of him. We're too damn liberal.
answer: Perhaps. But at least all this has made the Government see some sense about what men like Mr. Gandhi should be allowed, and what they should be denied. Things are going to change.

question: Where is Mr. Gandhi? The Prophet give me patience. My house is honored.
answer: The honor is ours. May I introduce Mr. Kallenbach. He's an old friend and his interest is in flowers. I presumed to tell him he could wander your gardens while we talked.

question: I'll send my gardener. I'm sure you'll have much to discuss. Gentlemen -- the hero of Champaran.
answer: Only the stubborn man of Champaran.

question: Mr. Patel you know. Mr. Maulana Azad -- a fellow Muslim... recently released from prison. Mr. Kripalani. And of course you know Mr. Nehru.
answer: I am beginning to know Mr. Nehru.

question: Yes?
answer: Nothing... nothing is working, sir -- buses... trains... the markets... There's not even any civilian staff here, sir... Everything has stopped.

question: Is it simply Delhi and Bombay?
answer: No, sir -- Karachi, Calcutta, Madras, Bangalore. It's, it's total. The Army had to take over the telegraph or we'd be cut off from the world.

question: I can't believe it...
answer: He's going to sell his own paper tomorrow in Bombay. They've called for a parade -- on Victoria Road.

question: Bapu...
answer: You too...

question: It seems less formal than "Mahatma." Since your arrest the riots have hardly stopped. Not big --; but they keep breaking out. I run to stop them... and Patel and Kripalani -- they are never at rest. But some English civilians have been killed, and the Army is attacking crowds with clubs -- and sometimes worse.
answer: Maybe I'm wrong... maybe we're not ready yet. In South Africa the numbers were small...

question: The Government's afraid, and they don't know what to do. But they're more afraid of terrorists than of you. The Viceroy has agreed to your release if you will speak for non- violence.
answer: I've never spoken for anything else.

question: Port arms, Sergeant Major. Load. They've had their warning -- no meetings. Sergeant Major -- Fire! Take your time. Take your time. Corporal! Over there.
answer: General Dyer, is it correct that you ordered your troops to fire at the thickest part of the crowd?

question: That is so.
answer: One thousand five hundred and sixteen casualties with one thousand six hundred and fifty bullets.

question: My intention was to inflict a lesson that would have an impact throughout all India. I think, probably -- yes. I did.
answer: But that was irrelevant to the point you were making?

question: That is correct.
answer: Could I ask you what provision you made for the wounded?

question: I was ready to help any who applied.
answer: General... how does a child shot with a 3-0-3 Enfield "apply" for help?

question: She wants to make her home with us -- and Gandhiji has agreed.
answer: You'd be Mr. Kallenbach.

question: ...And you would be Miss Slade.
answer: I prefer the name Gandhiji has given me -- Mirabehn.

question: It was a gift and it only worked a few weeks, but when Gandhi came home he struck on this idea. He calls it his ox-Ford. Comfortable -- and yet more our pace.
answer: Might Mr. Nehru be there too?

question: Might Mr. Nehru be there too?
answer: The irresponsible young Nehru is in prison -- again. Though there is a rumor that under pressure from your country, they will let him out -- again.

question: You can't know how closely we follow your struggle -- how many in England admired what you did in Bardoli. It must have taken enormous courage.
answer: Well, in this country one must decide if one is more afraid of the government or Gandhi. For us, it's Gandhi.

question: And you're German...
answer: Yes.

question: And do you feel Indian?
answer: No.

question: But you've been with him so long -- why?
answer: ...I'd come to believe I would never meet a truly honest man. And then I met one.

question: Not true! The secret is mastering the urge.
answer: He came Second Class.

question: Well, we can't expect miracles all the time. Your news I understand is not so good.
answer: No.

question: Come, come -- you will be my daughter...
answer: ...but then some rioting broke out between Hindus and Muslims -- violent, terrible... Whether it was provoked... But it gave them an excuse to impose martial law throughout Bengal. Some of the things the military have done...

question: Is the campaign weakening?
answer: The marches and protests are bigger if anything but with the censorship here they know more in England than we do, and it saps the courage to think you may be suffering alone.

question: They are not alone. And martial law only shows how desperate the British are. Is that homespun? Or cotton from Leeds?
answer: I -- I sent for it, from here. I dyed it myself.

question: What do the workers in England make of what we're doing? It must have produced hardship.
answer: It has. But you'd be surprised. They understand -- they really do. It's not the workers you have to worry about.

question: Good. Ba will have to teach you to spin too.
answer: I would rather march.

question: If we obtain our freedom by murder and bloodshed I want no part of it.
answer: It was one incident.

question: Tell that to the families of the policemen who died.
answer: Bapu -- the whole nation is marching. They wouldn't stop, even if we asked them to.

question: I've brought your drinking water. May I turn you? There is a little lemon juice in it. That is all. Herman has gone to meet Pandit Nehru -- there was a telegram. Almost everywhere it has stopped.
answer: When it is everywhere, then my prayers will be answered. Do you find me stubborn?

question: I don't know... I know you are right. I don't know that this is right.
answer: When I despair, I remember that all through history the way of truth and love has always won. There have been tyrants and murderers, and for a time they can seem invincible. But in the end they always fall. Think of it -- always... When you are in doubt that that is God's way, the way the world is meant to be... think of that. And then -- try to do it His way. And now -- could I have another feast of lemon juice?

question: Well, he certainly wasn't forgotten! And as soon as he got out he was back tramping the country, preaching non-violence and demanding a free India. Everybody knows another showdown's coming -- but when, and over what --
answer: Well, I read you account of that crowd in Calcutta and that he was twisting the Lion's tail again... ...and I knew something had to give. And I was determined to be here when it did.

question: How does a reporter in Central America learn that Gandhi was born in Porbandar anyway?
answer: Oh, I've been a Gandhi buff for a long time.

question: He certainly makes good copy. The other day Winston Churchill called him "that half-naked Indian fakir."
answer: I met him once.

question: You mean Gandhi?
answer: Back in South Africa... long time ago.

question: What was he like?
answer: Lots of hair... and a little like a college freshman -- trying to figure everything out.

question: "In every worthy wish of yours, I shall be your helpmate."
answer: "Take a fourth step, that we may be ever full of joy."

question: "I will ever live devoted to you, speaking words of love and praying for your happiness."
answer: "Take a fifth step, that we may serve the people."

question: "I will follow close behind you and help to serve the people."
answer: "Take a sixth step, that we may follow our vows in life."

question: "I will follow you in all our vows and duties."
answer: "Take the seventh step, that we may ever live as friends."

question: "You are my best friend... my highest guru, and my sovereign lord."
answer: Then I put a sweetened wheat cake in her mouth.

question: And I put a sweetened wheat cake in his mouth.
answer: And with that we were pronounced man and wife. We were both thirteen...

question: And with that we were pronounced man and wife. We were both thirteen...
answer: It's beautiful.

question: Even as a boy I thought so.
answer: Trying to keep track of you is making me change all my sleeping habits.

question: And you've come all this way because you think something is going to happen?
answer: Hm. Is it?

question: Perhaps. I've come here to think about it. Do you remember much of South Africa?
answer: A great deal.

question: I've traveled so far -- and thought so much. As you can see, my city was a sea city -- always filled with Hindus and Muslims and Sikhs and Jews and Persians. The temple where you were yesterday is of my family's sect, the Pranami. It was Hindu of course but the priests used to read from the Muslim Koran and the Hindu Gita, moving from one to the other as though it mattered not at all which book was read as long as God was worshipped. When I was a boy I used to sing a song in that temple
answer: You know what you're going to do.

question: It would have been very uncivil of me to let you make such a long trip for nothing.
answer: Where are you going?

question: All right -- he's breaking the law. What will he be depriving us of, two rupees of salt tax?
answer: It's not a serious attack on the revenue, sir. Its primary importance is symbolic.

question: Don't patronize me, Charles.
answer: No, sir. I -- in this climate, sir, nothing lives without water -- or salt. Our absolute control of it is a control on the pulse of India.

question: I have two of them bossing me now.
answer: We must get these to the printer. I know it will succeed. Even my mother is prepared to march.

question: And Jinnah?
answer: He's waiting. He's not prepared to accept it will mean as much as you think.

question: Wait and see... wait and see... You've done me a great service.
answer: It would have been uncivil of me to have let you make such a long trip for nothing. Is it over if they arrest you now?

question: Not if they arrest me -- or a thousand -- or ten thousand. It is not only generals who know how to plan campaigns.
answer: What if they don't arrest you? What if they don't react at all?

question: He's addressed this letter directly to you, has he?
answer: Yes, sir, he has. The usual -- India's salt belongs to India -- but then he says flatly that he personally is going to lead a raid tomorrow on the Dharasana Salt Works.

question: Thank him for his letter, and put him in jail.
answer: Yes, sir. Yes, sir. It will be my pleasure.

question: And Fields, keep that salt works open.
answer: Yes, sir!

question: Stop! Wait a minute!
answer: Yes, I have heard of Life Magazine. I have even heard of Margaret Bourke- White. But I don't know why either should be interested in an old man sitting in prison when the world is blowing itself to pieces.

question: You're the only man I know who makes his own clothes.
answer: Ah, but for me that's not much of an accomplishment. No -- prison is rather agreeable to me, and there is no doubt that after the war, independence will come. My only worry is what shape it will take. Jinnah has --

question: Stop! Now go on -- just as you were. "...what shape it will take." Jinnah has -- what?
answer: Jinnah has -- has cooperated with the British. It has given him power and the freedom to speak, and he has filled the Muslims with fears of what will happen to them in a country that is predominantly Hindu. That I find hard to bear -- even in prison.

question: I do not see it as the solution of the twentieth century's problems!
answer: I have a friend who keeps telling me how much it costs him to keep me in poverty. But I know happiness does not come with things -- even twentieth century things. It can come from work, and pride in what you do. It will not necessarily be "progress" for India if she simply imports the unhappiness of the West.

question: But do you really believe you could use non-violence against someone like Hitler?
answer: Not without defeats -- and great pain. But are there no defeats in this war -- no pain? What you cannot do is accept injustice. From Hitler -- or anyone. You must make the injustice visible -- be prepared to die like a soldier to do so.

question: Is my finger supposed to be wrapped around that?
answer: No. That is what you get for distracting me.

question: What do you expect when you talk like that?
answer: I expect you to show as much patience as I am now. Every enemy is a human being -- even the worst of them. And he believes he is right and you are a beast. And if you beat him over the head you will only convince him. But you suffer, to show him that he is wrong, your sacrifice creates an atmosphere of understanding -- if not with him, then in the hearts of the rest of the community on whom he depends. If you are right, you will win -- after much pain. If you are wrong, well, then, only you will suffer the blows.

question: ...not at all. Bapu has always said there were two kinds of slavery in India -- one for women, one for the untouchables -- and he has always fought against both.
answer: Does it rankle, being separated from him this way?

question: Yes... but we see each other in the day.
answer: But not at night...

question: In Hindu philosophy the way to God is to free yourself of possessions -- and the passions that inflame to anger and jealousy. Bapu has always struggled to find the way to God.
answer: You mean he -- he gave up -- married life.

question: Four times he tried -- and failed. But then he took a solemn vow...
answer: And he has never broken it?

question: Aren't you being a little overprotective?
answer: Tomorrow. Tomorrow photograph him.

question: I came all this way because I believed the picture of Independence Day was of him here alone.
answer: It is violence, and the fear of violence, that have made today what it is... Give him the dignity of his grief.

question: And while we're sitting here feeding goats, what will happen to all the Muslims in India and the Hindus in Pakistan?
answer: Gandhi will pray for them...

question: Bapu, forgive me -- I've cheated. I could have come earlier. But your fast has helped. These last days people's minds have begun to turn to this bed -- and away from last night's atrocity. But now it is enough.
answer: All that has happened is that I've grown a little thinner.

question: Tomorrow five thousand Muslim students of all ages are marching here in Calcutta -- for peace. And five thousand Hindu students are marching with them. It is all organized.
answer: I'm glad -- but it will not be enough.

question: Bapu, you are not so young anymore.
answer: Don't worry for me -- death will be a deliverance. I cannot watch the destruction of all I have lived for.

question: Go -- try -- God by with you.
answer: Eat. Eat! I am going to hell -- but not with your death on my soul.

question: Only God decides who goes to hell...
answer: I -- I killed a child... I smashed his head against a wall.

question: Why? Why?
answer: They killed my son -- my boy! The Muslims killed my son... they killed him.

question: You really are going to Pakistan, then? You are a stubborn man.
answer: I'm simply going to prove to Muslims there, and Hindus here, that the only devils in the world are those running around in our own hearts -- and that's where all our battles ought to be fought.

question: And what kind of a warrior have you been in that warfare?
answer: Not a very good one. That's why I have so much tolerance for the other scoundrels of the world. Ask Panditji to -- to consider what we've discussed. Enough.

question: One more.
answer: You're a temptress.

question: Just an admirer...
answer: Nothing's more dangerous, especially for an old man.
